label: AL rdfs:label@en
definition: AL IAO:0000115@en
comment: AL rdfs:comment@en

label: planned process
definition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.

label: material processing
definition: A planned process which results in physical changes in a specified input material

label: process by mechanism
definition: A planned process which has one or more action specification parts in its plan specification that control a mechanism.
comment: A convenience class for organizing processes by their physical mechanism or digital algorithm. An action may be physical, like pushing a button or setting a dial, or may be about running some software.

label: material processing by mechanism
definition: Material processing which has one or more action specifications in its plan specification.
comment: A plan specification may manipulate parameters [variables / dimensions] to create an environment in flux that transforms/changes/affects the materials

label: process by objective
definition: A planned process which has one or more objective specification parts in its plan specification.
comment: Implicitly this process must have a part which can sense when its one or more objectives are complete, so that it can halt. Process objectives might be classed as primary, secondary or tertiary but that may be relative to the needs of a supply chain.

label: material processing by objective
definition: Material processing which has one or more objective specification parts in its plan specification.

label: energy modulation
definition: Material processing which involves a change in energy applied to or inherent in a material.

label: thermal energy modulation
definition: An energy modulation in which thermal energy (heat) is applied to or removed from a material or its environment.

label: heating of material
definition: An energy modulation in which thermal energy (heat) is applied to a material or its environment.

label: cooling of material
definition: An energy modulation in which thermal energy (heat) is removed from a material or its environment.

label: force modulation
definition: A material processing by mechanism in which force is applied to or removed from a material or its environment.

label: separating material
definition: A material processing by mechanism in which materials are separated.

label: combining material
definition: A material processing by mechanism in which materials are combined.

label: molecular mechanism by reaction type
definition: A molecular mechanism categorized by its reaction type.

label: covalent reaction
definition: A molecular mechanism by reaction type involving a covalent reaction.

label: non-covalent reaction
definition: A molecular mechanism by reaction type involving a non-covalent reaction.

label: molecular mechanism by spatial location
definition: A molecular mechanism categorized by the region in which reactions are taking place.

label: surface mechanism
definition: A molecular mechanism where reactions are occurring at some surface boundary.

label: bulk molecular mechanism
definition: A molecular mechanism where reactions are occurring throughout a mixture.

label: food transformation process
definition: A process involving the physical transformation of a food source or food product into some derived organic material or food product

label: food cutting process
definition: A process of cutting food into smaller pieces, chunks or slices.

label: food fermentation
definition: A fermentation process in which either carbohydrates, proteins or fats are modified through microbial, enzymatic and/or other biological process.

label: meat roasting
definition: Roasting is a baking process when the food being baked is meats

label: food physical forming
definition: Modification through physical treatment to affect the shape quality of a food product.

label: food solvent extraction
definition: Extraction of substance(s) from a food source using a solvent such as alcohol, hexane, or ethanol.

label: food milling
definition: The process of milling grain into flour, usually performed by a grist mill, corn mill or flour mill.

label: food grinding
definition: The process of grinding food such as meat.

label: food mincing
definition: The process of cutting food such as meat into very fine pieces.

label: deboning
definition: The process of removing bone from animal meat.

label: food evaporation process
definition: A food evaporation process is the process of removing water from a food.

parent: cooking in small amount of fat or oil
label: shallow frying
definition: A form of frying characterized by the use of minimal cooking oil or fat (compared to shallow frying or deep frying); typically using just enough oil to lubricate the pan. A pan fry takes place at lower heat than does a saut√©.

label: food scalding
definition: A method of precooking food where a liquid is heated to just below the boiling point. Often used to retard the spoiling of milk.

label: food cleaning
definition: The process of cleaning food to separate other environmental materials or body substances.

label: food dehulling
definition: Dehulling is the process of removing the hulls (or chaff) from beans and other seeds.

label: corn husking
definition: Husking of corn is the process of removing its outer layers, leaving only the cob or seed rack of the corn

label: food seasoning process
definition: A process of applying a seasoning mixture to a given food.

label: food packaging process
definition: A process that applies packaging material to a food product for preservation, shipping and/or presentation purposes.

label: ikajime
definition: Ikejime is a method of slaughtering fish to maintain the quality of its meat. The technique originated in Japan, but is now in widespread use. It involves the insertion of a spike quickly and directly into the hindbrain, usually located slightly behind and above the eye, thereby causing immediate brain death.
comment: When spiked correctly, the fish fins flare and the fish relaxes, immediately ceasing all motion. Destroying the brain and the spinal cord of the fish will prevent reflex action from happening; such muscle movements would otherwise consume adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in the muscle, and as a result produce lactic acid and ammonia, making the fish sour, soggy and less tasteful. Furthermore, the blood contained in the fish flesh retracts to the gut cavity, which produces a better coloured and flavoured fillet, and prolongs shelf life. [Wikipedia]

label: food harvesting
definition: A process which takes in some food material from an individual or community of plant or animal organisms in a given context and time, and outputs a precursor or consumable food product. This may include a part of an organism or the whole, and may involve killing the organism.
comment: This includes harvesting from plants, hunting a deer, or milking process of a cow.  The food is derived from part or whole of a single organism species (with perhaps a few exceptions, such as lichen).

label: winterization of oil
definition: Winterization of oil is a process that uses a solvent and cold temperatures to separate lipids and other desired oil compounds from waxes. Winterization is a type of fractionation, the general process of separating the triglycerides found in fats and oils, using the difference in their melting points, solubility, and volatility.

label: shell removal process
definition: A process which separates a culinary nut's shell from its meat, leaving the meat part more or less intact.

label: food peeling
definition: peeling is the process of removing the outer covering, layer or skin from a fruit, vegetable, or plant or animal (such as a shrimp).

label: cooking by dry heat
definition: Cooked at moderate to high levels of heat in which no liquid is added and only small amounts of fat may be added to prevent sticking.
comment: LanguaL

label: food baking
definition: Cooked without moisture, covered or uncovered, in an oven.

label: broiling or grilling
definition: Cooked without moisture under or over intense direct heat.

label: charcoal broiling
definition: Cooked without moisture over direct heat from a charcoal fire.

label: griddle cooking
definition: Cooking on a flat surface at medium heat with only a sufficient amount of fat used to prevent sticking.

label: cooked by popping
definition: Cooking by agitating the food over a dry, high heat source, resulting in exploding.

label: food toasting
definition: Cooking with direct heat until the surface of the food is browned, usually associated with bread or sandwiches.

label: cooking by microwave
definition: Cooking in a microwave oven.

label: cooking by moist heat
definition: Cooking in varying amounts of water, water-based liquid or steam.
comment: LanguaL curation note: If the food absorbs a significant amount of water, also used *REHYDRATED* or *WATER ADDED*.

label: cooking in water or water-based liquid
definition: A process of cooking by moist heat which is effected by hot water or water-based liquid in a container.

parent: cooking in water or water-based liquid
label: boiling in container
definition: A cooking in water or water-based liquid process in which the liquid is boiling.
comment: Water at standard atmospheric pressure (in other words, at sea level) will boil at a temperature of 100 degrees C (212 degrees F).

label: boiling and then draining
definition: Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F.; water that is not absorbed into the food product is discarded after cooking.

label: boiling in large amount of liquid
definition: Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F. Liquid to solid ratio is greater than 2:1.

label: boiling in small amount of liquid
boiling without draining
definition: Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F. The water incorporates itself into the product being cooked or is not discarded when cooking is complete.

parent: cooking in water or water-based liquid
label: cooking by braising
definition: Browned initially in fat and then tightly covered and cooked over low heat in a small amount of water.

parent: cooking in water or water-based liquid
label: cooking by simmering
definition: Cooking in a moderate amount of liquid at just below the boiling point.

label: steaming with pressure
definition: Cooked in a pressure cooker.

label: steaming without pressure
definition: Cooked suspended above boiling water.

label: cooking with added fat or oil
definition: Cooked by adding fat or oil to those foods that do not contain fat or oil that would render during the cooking process.

parent: cooking with added fat or oil
label: cooking in small amount of fat or oil
definition: Cooked with sufficient fat or oil to coat and moisten the food being prepared, but not cooked in enough fat or oil to immerse the food.
comment: Use *griddle cooking* when only enough fat or oil is used to prevent sticking.

parent: cooking in small amount of fat or oil
label: saut√©ing
definition: Cooking in a very small amount of very hot fat, turning and browning the food on all sides.

parent: cooking in small amount of fat or oil
label: stir-frying
definition: Cooked by frying foods quickly over high heat, stirring constantly. Only enough cooking oil is used to coat the bottom of the pan.

parent: cooking with added fat or oil
label: deep-frying process
definition: Cooked in hot fat or oil deep enough to immerse the food entirely.

label: cooking with inherent fat or oil
definition: Cooked in fat or oil rendered from the food being prepared.

label: heating container
definition: A food cooking method in which heat is transferred to the outside of a container.

label: heating container in double boiler
definition: Heating a container that is placed in another container filled with boiling water.
synonym: cooked over boiling water|double boiler cooked

label: heating container by water bath
definition: Heating a container that is placed in another container filled with water kept near the boiling point.

label: heating container by immersion in water or steam
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the food is cooked in a closed container such as a pouch immersed in hot water or steam.

parent: cooking with added fat or oil
label: shallow frying process
definition: A chinese cooking technique similar to sauteing in which thick slices or chunks of floured or battered ingredients are slow seared over moderate to low heat.
definition source: Kuo, The key to chinese cooking, Knopf, 1977, p.87

parent: cooking in water or water-based liquid
label: steeping
definition: Extracting flavor and other components from food sources by immersion in water, usually at near-boiling temperature.

label: food reheating
definition: A process to bring an already fully cooked product to serving temperature.
comment: LanguaL curation note: Do not use for a process that completes the cooking of a partially cooked food.

label: food reheating in pan or cooking utensil
double steaming
definition: A Chinese cooking technique to prepare delicate food such as bird nests, shark fins, etc. The food is covered with water and put in a covered ceramic jar and the jar is then steamed for several hours.
comment: This technique ensures there is no loss of liquid or moisture (its essences) from the food being cooked, hence it is often used with expensive ingredients like Chinese herbal medicines. [Wikipedia]

label: rotisserie roasting
definition: Rotisserie is a style of roasting where meat is skewered on a spit and revolves over a flame or other heat source.
comment: The rotation cooks the meat evenly in its own juices and allows easy access for continuous basting if desired. [Wikipedia]

label: searing
definition: Searing is a technique used in grilling, roasting, braising, saut√©ing, etc. that cooks the surface of the food at high temperature so that a brownish crust forms by Maillard reaction and denaturation of proteins.
comment: A similar technique, browning, is typically used to sear or brown all sides of a particular piece of meat, fish, poultry, etc. before finishing it in the oven. To obtain the desired brown crust, the meat surface must exceed 300 ¬∞F (150 ¬∞C), so searing requires the meat surface be free of water, which boils at around 212 ¬∞F (100 ¬∞C).
example of use: Searing is often applied to pan-fried meat, poultry or fish

label: blind baking
comment: LanguaL curation note: Use when a pie crust or other pastry is baked without the filling.

parent: cooking with added fat or oil
label: pressure frying process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Use when e.g. meat and cooking oil are brought to high temperatures while pressure is held high enough that the water within is prevented from boiling off.

label: component substitution process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Use the appropriate narrower term for a food product that was prepared from a natural food product by removing an endogeneous component and adding a component of the same class. Index the specific component added under *INGREDIENT ADDED*, regardless of its level.

label: food noncertified color addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a color is added that is exempt from certification and considered safe for use.

label: artificial carbonation process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when carbon dioxide has been added to a food product at any level. Damion Dooley's note: converted to a process

label: food treatment process
definition: Used to specifically characterize a food product based on the treatment or processes applied to the product or any indexed ingredient. The processes include adding, substituting or removing components or modifying the food or component, e.g., through fermentation.
comment: LanguaL curation note: This term is for CLASSIFICATION ONLY; DO NOT USE term in indexing. Use a more precise narrower term.

label: water removal to reconstitution ratio 3 plus 1 or higher
water removal to reconstitution ratio 2 plus 1
water removal to reconstitution ratio 1 plus 1
microbial/enzymatic modification process
definition: A food modification process by microbial or enzymatic action which results in molecular changes in any food component.
comment: LanguaL curation note: If salt, sugar or other food additive is used to aid in the modification process, index it by the appropriate term under *INGREDIENT ADDED*.

label: food irradiation process
definition: A physical/chemical modification process in which a food product or component is irradiated for any purpose.

label: multi-component food fermentation
definition: A food fermentation process in which significant amounts of two or more components (i.e. carbohydrate and protein, carbohydrate and fat, protein and fat, or all three) are modified through microbial processes. Enzymatic or other biological processes may also be involved.

label: physical/chemical modification process
definition: A food modification process where physical or chemical changes are effected in any food ingredient through a physical or non-enzymatic chemical process.

label: food certified color addition process
definition: A food color addition process in which color that must be certified by batch as safe to use is added at any level.

label: demineralizing process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when one or more naturally present minerals have been fully or partially removed.

label: water removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for a liquid or solid product from which a significant amount of water (25% or more of the original weight of the water) has been removed. If dehydration is the primary preservation method, also index *DEHYDRATED OR DRIED*. For soups that require the addition of water, use the appropriate narrower term regardless of whether water was removed or not. Do not use for products that have been rehydrated.

label: food modification process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the food product underwent mechanical, chemical or enzymatic modification that has affected the texture, flavor or other characteristic of the product.

parent: food component addition process|water addition or removal process
label: water addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for a liquid or solid product to which water was added beyond its natural water level. If a single-strength standard for the product exists, use the appropriate narrower term under *WATER ADDED*.

label: food color addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a color substance is added to a food at any level.

label: alcoholization process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when alcohol is added for flavor or taste, for example, brandied peaches or cold-pack cheese food with port wine.

label: fat removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products that contain less than 60% of the fat naturally present in the food source (more precisely, the part of the food source.) more specific fat levels, which vary from one product type to another, are specified in the extended scope notes for *FAT PARTIALLY REMOVED* and *FAT FULLY REMOVED* in the manual.

label: food instantizing
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for food products modified to reduce cooking time or to enhance dispersion characteristics of powdered or granulated products.

label: food hydrogenation process
definition: The saturating or hardening of a vegetable oil to which hydrogen has been chemically added to convert it to a fat.

label: carbonation process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when carbon dioxide is added or introduced by processing. Excludes naturally carbonated water, which is indexed under food source *MINERAL WATER*.  Damion Dooley's note: converted to a process

label: food aeration process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products with which a substantial amount of air has been mixed through mechanical action. Do not use when air was introduced primarily through chemical action or through fermentation.

label: candying process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for whole fruit or pieces of fruit are permeated by sugar to result in a product with sugar solids over 70% (e.g., candied citrus peel or candied cherry). Not used for sugar-coated products or for such products as candied sweet potatoes or glazed carrots, which are merely sweetened by cooking in syrup.

label: pickling
definition: A process of preserving or extending the shelf life of food by either anaerobic fermentation in brine or immersion in vinegar.
comment: LanguaL curation note: Also index by other applicable terms from *MICROBIALLY/ ENZYMATICALLY MODIFIED*.  LanguaL definition: "Treated with acid that may be produced by fermentation or added and/or with salt brine, often in the presence of spices or herbs, producing changes in flavor and texture."

label: food texturing process
definition: Modified through physical and/or chemical treatment to promote or affect the tactile quality and appearance of a food product.

label: nutrient or dietary substance addition process
definition: A food is 'enriched' when nutrients are added to it to replace those that are lost in processing; a food is 'fortified' when nutrients that were never present are added to it.
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a chemical constituent is added for nutrient supplementation. Not used when the constituent is added to improve the functional properties of the food product. If the purpose of the constituent is not known, use the appropriate index term.

label: food bleaching process
definition: Treated with chemicals to reduce color, primarily to whiten, e.g., bleached flour.

label: acidification process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used  when acid is added to a food product at any level.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Adding with acid(s) in order to reduce pH below the range where some microorganisms can grow

label: lactose conversion process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when all or part of the lactose in milk is converted to glucose and galactose through enzymatic action.

label: food alkalization process
definition: Treated with a solution of alkali (primarily potassium or sodium carbonate). In cacao, alkalization neutralizes acids and leads to changes in flavor and color. In fats and oils, treatment with alkali leads to saponification of free fatty acids; soap and alkali are then removed.

label: food filling process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Applies to all filled or stuffed products, including pies and sandwiches.

label: fat substitution process
definition: Food product prepared from a natural food product by removing endogenous fat and adding fat from a different source, e.g., egg substitute, in which egg fat is replaced by vegetable oil.

parent: cooking by moist heat|physical/chemical modification process
label: food parboiling process (grain)
definition: Treated with moist heat to soften the grain and to transfer nutrients from the bran to the endosperm.

label: food component addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: A food product is characterized by its main ingredient (food source and part); the addition of secondary ingredients is considered a treatment applied to the product. Secondary ingredients are indexed according to rules that are based on the order of predominance by weight (not counting water) as seen from the label statement, formulation or recipe and/or from the amount of the ingredient as percentage of total product weight. The general rule is:  an ingredient is always indexed if it is the second ingredient in order of predominance, if it is used as a filling, or if it is part of the product name(e.g., raisin bread). Specific rules are given in the scope note for the individual ingredient added; these rules specify more exhaustive indexing. For example, *MUSHROOM ADDED* is indexed regardless of ingredient position. another specific rule is given in the scope note for *SALTED*:  Use if the level of salt is more than 4%. Such a rule is used only when the percentage level can be inferred from the list of ingredients.

label: single component food fermentation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products in which either carbohydrates, proteins or fats were modified through microbial processes. Enzymatic or other biological processes may also be involved. If two or more of these components are modified in significant amounts, index under *FERMENTED/MODIFIED, MULTIPLE COMPONENT*.

label: dilution process to 15-49% of single strength
sodium removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when naturally present sodium has been fully or partially removed. Index also by the appropriate term under *SALT OR SODIUM SPECIAL CLAIM OR USE*.

label: dilution process to 50-99% of single strength
food component separation process
definition: A component separation process at the very least removes one component from an initial entity.  The removed component may be captured as a process output for reuse if not destroyed in the process of removal.
comment: LanguaL curation note: Use the appropriate term under *COMPONENT REMOVED* to indicate the permanent full or partial removal of a nutritional/chemical component naturally present in the part of plant or animal used.

label: food rolling process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for a grain in which the kernels have been physically compressed between heated rollers.

label: food thawing process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the product or any indexed ingredient was frozen and then thawed. Excludes freeze-dried products and freeze-flo products.

label: carbonation by fermentation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when carbon dioxide produced by fermentation remains noticeable in the food product. Damion Dooley's note: converted to a process

label: partial fat removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products that contain between 10-20% and 60% of the fat naturally present in the food source. Examples are breakfast cocoa, low fat milk and low-fat cottage cheese.

label: full fat removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products that contain less than 10-20% of the fat naturally present in the food source. Examples are skim milk, low-fat cocoa and dry-curd cottage cheese.

label: enzymatic modification process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products in which one or more components were converted through the addition of enzymes or through activation of endogenous enzymes.

label: curing or aging
definition: Modified through complex enzymatic or microbial processes resulting in physicochemical changes in particular with respect to texture, flavor, color or shelf life of the food product. Such changes may be induced by the introduction of certain chemicals, such as sodium sulfite, salt, sugar, or other substances, such as phenolics, in dry or liquid form and often aided by smoke. Cheese should always be indexed by the appropriate narrower term under *LACTIC ACID-OTHER AGENT FERMENTED*.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Curing refers to various food preservation and flavouring processes, especially of meat or fish, by the addition of a combination of salt and other ingredients, with eventual partial drying and biological maturation

label: water addition or removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when water is added or removed in order to change the total solids-to-liquids ratio of a food product.

parent: food component addition process|water addition process
label: rehydration process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for a product that is prepared by adding water or a water-based liquid (milk, juice, broth) to a dehydrated or concentrated product or to a product that contains an indexed dehydrated ingredient plus water to rehydrate that ingredient. Examples:  juice or juice drink from concentrate; milk reconstituted from dry or concentrated milk; soaked dried beans or stewed fruit; biscuit dough (prepared by rehydrating flour); soup made from dehydrated ingredients; cooked noodles or boiled rice. If the resulting product contains water beyond its natural water level, also index *WATER ADDED*.
synonym: made from concentrate|moistened|previously concentrated|reconstituted to liquid|soaked

label: food flaking process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used only for breakfast cereals made by forcing cooked particles of grain or tiny pellets of dough between very heavy rollers that convert each piece into a single flake.

label: food meat liquid injection process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when liquid is injected into a meat or poultry is prebasted. Do not confuse with *WATER ADDED*.

label: alcohol removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products from which alcohol has been removed.

label: full alcohol removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products from which alcohol has been removed to less than 0.5% alcohol by volume.

label: partial alcohol removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products from which alcohol has been removed to 0.5% or more alcohol by volume.

label: curing or aging 2 weeks to 1 month
curing or aging 12 months or over
lactose removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when lactose is removed from the food product as when washing curd for cheese preparation. When lactose content is reduced by enzymatic conversion of lactose, use *LACTOSE CONVERTED*.

label: clotting enzyme addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a clotting enzyme is added to a food product at any level.

label: food homogenization or emulsification process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for products in which two or more phases are mixed very finely but not at the molecular level. A very fine dispersion of a solid in a liquid is called a suspension. A very fine dispersion of one liquid in another immiscible liquid is called an emulsion.

label: partial fat removal process, 50% or more remaining
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for food products that have had fat partially removed to leave more than 50% fat from a full fat product. An example would 2% milk where full fat milk is 4%.

label: partial fat removal process, less than 50% remaining
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for food products that have had fat removed to leave less than 50% fat from a full fat product. Examples would be 1% milk or 1/2% milk, where full fat milk is 4%.

label: food extrusion
definition: Modified through a physical or chemical procedure by forcing a food mixture through a die to achieve a particular shape.

label: food coating or covering process
exact synonym: glazing process|food covering process|food coating process

label: chocolate coating or covering process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Includes chocolate coatings for such products as candy and ice cream products as well as icings and frostings for such products as cakes and doughnuts.

label: carob coating or covering process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for foods that have a coating or icing made from carob.

label: food aeration by whipping
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when foods or liquids (or a combination) are aerated by vigorously mixing them using a whip, whisk, spoon, spatula, rotary beater or electric mixer.

label: food aeration by creaming
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a solid fat (butter, margarine, shortening) is aerated to a creamy appearance, often with the addition of sugar.

label: food flattening process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for any process such as rolling or pounding that is applied to dough, paste or meat (veal, chicken breast) in order to flatten the appearance.

label: seed roasting
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used primarily for processing of seeds, such as coffee, spices, nuts, and cacao beans.

label: acid reduction process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a juice, typically orange, has undergone a process specified in 21 CFR 146.148 to reduce the adicity of the food.

label: marinading
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a food such as meat, fish or vegetables are soaked in a seasoned liquid in order to absorb flavor and, in some instances, to be tenderized. Most marinades contain an acid (lemon juice, vinegar, wine) and herbs or spices; the acid ingredient serves as the tenderizer.

label: rind removal process
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for food products (typically fruit, cheese or meat) that have had the rind removed.

label: sourdough addition process
comment: LanguaL curation note: If wheat sourdough was added use also *WHEAT ADDED [H0319]*. If rye sourdough was added use also *RYE ADDED [H0337]*.

label: food animal rendering
definition: Rendering is a process that converts waste animal tissue into stable, value-added materials. Rendering can refer to any processing of animal byproducts into more useful materials, or more narrowly to the rendering of whole animal fatty tissue into purified fats like lard or tallow. Rendering can be carried out on an industrial, farm, or kitchen scale.

label: food micro-encapsulation process
definition: Micro-encapsulation is a process in which tiny particles or droplets are surrounded by a coating to give small capsules many useful properties. In a relatively simplistic form, a microcapsule is a small sphere with a uniform wall around it.
comment: The material inside the microcapsule is referred to as the core, internal phase, or fill, whereas the wall is sometimes called a shell, coating, or membrane. Most microcapsules have diameters between a few micrometers and a few millimeters. The definition has been expanded, and includes most foods. Every class of food ingredient has been encapsulated; flavors are the most common. The technique of microencapsulation depends on the physical and chemical properties of the material to be encapsulated.[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro-encapsulation]  LanguaL curation note: Used for the coating of microscopic particles with another material.

label: preservation by adding chemicals
definition: Preservation by adding chemical preservatives (e.g., sorbic acid, sodium benzoate, BHT, calcium proprionate) to suppress or inhibit undesirable microorganisms or enzyme activity.

label: food sterilization before filling
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a food product is sterilized by holding at a high temperature before filling; the container may be sterilized before or after filling.

parent: physical/chemical modification process|preservation by adding inorganic acids or salts|preservation by reducing water activity
label: food salting
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when salting is used for preservation. The salt content of the food is generally 8% or higher (e.g. salted fish, etc.).

parent: food modification process|preservation by reducing water activity
label: food smoking
definition: Smoking is the process of flavoring, browning, cooking, or preserving food by exposing it to smoke from burning or smoldering material, most often wood.
comment: In the past, smoking was a useful preservation tool, in combination with other techniques, most commonly salt-curing or drying. For some long-smoked foods, the smoking time also served to dry the food. Drying, curing, or other techniques can render the interior of foods inhospitable to bacterial life, while the smoking gives the vulnerable exterior surfaces an extra layer of protection. [Wikipedia]|LanguaL curation note: Used when smoking is used for preservation.

label: food preservation process
definition: The methods contributing to the prevention or retardation of microbial, enzymatic or oxidative spoilage and thus to the extension of shelf life. Index all methods for which information is available, even if a corresponding descriptor has already been used in *H. TREATMENT APPLIED*. Preservation descriptors refer to the finished food as a whole with these exceptions: (1) if the components of a multi-component food, such as cream pie, are preservation by different methods, index all methods; (2)  if chemical preservatives are declared on the label, always index them even if it is known that the preservative was introduced through or is only present in a component or ingredient of the food; and (3) if the preservation method for an ingredient is declared on the label (such as brie cheese made from pasteurized milk) index it. Also use *INGREDIENT preservation by THERMAL PROCESSING* or *INGREDIENT preservation by IRRADIATION* when ingredients have been pasteurized, ultrapasteurized, sterilized or irradiated.
comment: LanguaL curation note: This term is for CLASSIFICATION ONLY; DO NOT USE term in indexing. Use a more precise narrower term.

label: preservation by treatment with chemicals
definition: Preservation by immersing in or spraying with liquids (e.g., sulfite solutions) or surrounding with gases (e.g., ethylene oxide, propylene oxide or sulfur dioxide) to destroy undesirable microorganisms or inactivate enzymes. Diffusion and chemical reaction may create a residue in the food product that contributes to continuing preservation.

label: chemical food preservation process
definition: Preservation by use of chemical to destroy, suppress or inhibit undesirable microorganisms or enzyme activity.

label: food sterilization after filling
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a food product was sterilized by holding at a high temperature after filling.

label: preservation by storage in modified atmosphere
definition: Preservation by storage in an atmosphere in which the concentrations of oxygen and carbon dioxide are different from those in air. This reduces microbial and enzymatic activity; often used commercially in conjunction with refrigeration (e.g., refrigerated rail cars) for fresh meat and produce.

label: drying under reduced pressure
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the pressure is reduced to increase the efficiency of water removal.

label: sterilization by irradiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used for a food product that has been packed in a hermetically sealed container and rendered commercially sterile by ionizing radiation (e.g. 24-28 kGy).
FoodEx2 label: Sterilising by action of ionizing radiation. Common name is 'Gamma irradiation'

label: food sterilization by hot filling and cooling
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a sterile product is filled into a container at approximately 212 degrees F and cooled promptly after sealing.

label: surface pasteurization or disinfection by ultraviolet irradiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when sufficient ultraviolet radiation is applied to destroy most pathogenic and spoilage organisms present on the surface or to inhibit sprouting of stored agricultural produce and destroy storage pests. When followed by refrigeration, also index *preservation by CHILLING*.

parent: food evaporation process|preservation by reducing water activity
label: dehydration or drying
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the water activity has been lowered enough to achieve preservation. Also index *WATER REMOVED* in *H. TREATMENT APPLIED*.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Transformation of moist food/feed into its solid - dry form due to almost complete subtraction of water

label: heat drying process
definition: Drying by heat.

label: pasteurization by irradiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when sufficient radiation (e.g. 10 kGy) is applied to destroy most patho-genic and food spoilage organisms. Also index *preservation by CHILLING*.

label: heat treatment food preservation
definition: Preservation by the use of high temperature for a time sufficient to reduce or destroy undesirable microorganisms and enzyme activity. [FDA CFSAN 1995]
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Treating with heat with one of different techniques (for preservation)

parent: food component separation process|food preservation process
label: food filtration
definition: Preservation by filtering out yeasts and molds, generally followed by aseptic packaging. FDA CFSAN 1995

label: preservation by ionizing radiation
definition: Preservation by irradiation, primarily by gamma radiation.

label: food sterilization by heating
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the product is rendered commercially sterile by holding at high temperature before or after it is packed in a hermetically sealed container.
exact synonym: canning (sterilized and hermetically packed)|preservation by canning

label: osmotic dehydration
definition: Reduction of water in the product by osmosis.

label: aseptic filling and sealing of food
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a sterile product is filled in a sterile atmosphere into a sterile container. For further detail see 21 CFR 113.3(a).
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Process of filling sterilised food into a pre-sterilised packaging (usually, but not necessarily, flexible sealable containers)

label: food sterilization by hot filling, held hot and cooling
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a sterile product is filled into a container at approximately 212 degrees F., sealed, and held hot temporarily to complete processing before cooling.

label: freeze-drying
definition: Dehydration by sublimation under reduced pressure while frozen. Usually the product is not stored frozen.

label: food chilling
definition: Cooling and keeping at a temperature between 30¬∞F and 45¬∞F (-1¬∞C and 7¬∞C). Regarding food preservation regulations, the temperature range depends on national legislation.
comment: LanguaL curation note: Preservation methods that imply subsequent chilling are: *PASTEURIZED BY IRRADIATION*, *PASTEURIZED BY HEAT*, *preservation by CHEMICALS *, *preservation by FERMENTATION*, *SURFACE PASTEURIZED BY ULTRAVIOLET*, *preservation by STORAGE IN MODIFIED ATMOSPHERE*, *preservation by FILTRATION*.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Lowering in temperature, but still above the freezing point, to aid preservation

label: food quick freezing
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Preserving by freezing sufficiently rapidly to retain flavor and nutritional value. In this case, food in small forms, like berries and small fruits, tends to keep free flowing parts (individually quick frozen)

label: spray-drying
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when liquids and low-viscosity pastes or purees are dried by atomisation. Example: milk.

label: shelf-drying under normal pressure
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when water is removed from products placed in trays on shelves under atmospheric pressure. Example: vegetables, fruits.

label: pasteurization by heating
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the product is held at a temperature of 60-150 ¬∞C (140-300 ¬∞F) for a time sufficient to destroy most pathogenic and food spoilage organisms. When followed by refrigeration, also index *preservation by CHILLING*.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Subject to heat treatment with a time-temperature combination that guarantees the inactivation of all pathogenic microbial flora to such extent not to represent a health hazard. For example, in milk the parameters are 72 ¬∞C for 15 seconds (continuous flow pasteurization) or 63 ¬∞C for 30.minutes (batch pasteurization)

label: food freezing
definition: Preservation by freezing a food product and keeping it at a temperature below the freezing point (20-30 degrees F) without regard to the product's physical state.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Preserving by freezing sufficiently rapidly to avoid spoilage and microbial growth.

label: food brining
definition: Immersed in a salt brine strong enough to suppress enzyme activity and growth of undesirable organisms.

label: preservation by irradiation
definition: Preservation by the use of radiation to destroy or suppress undesirable microorganisms or enzyme activity.

label: food dry salting
definition: Packed in dry salt in sufficient quantity to suppress enzyme activity or growth of undesirable organisms.

label: natural heat drying
definition: Dried by natural heat, usually through exposure to the sun. Includes field-dried products such as grains and dry beans. These products are included also if they have been artificially dried to return them to normal dry state, e.g. grain that has been artificially dried after harvest.

label: chilling or freezing
definition: Preservation by cooling and storage at low temperature (chilling at around 0-5¬∞C (32 to 41¬∞F), freezing at -18¬∞C (0¬∞F))  to prevent or retard microbial or enzymatic spoilage.
comment: LanguaL curation note: In order to comply with labelling requirements, it must be specified if it is chilling or freezing.

label: artificial heat drying
definition: Drying by the application of artificial heat.

label: preservation by reducing water activity
definition: Preservation method that lowers the water activity (relative humidity) of a food product. This is accomplished by using mechanical dehydration equipment, by natural drying, by adding salt, sugar or other agents to the food or by surface drying during a refrigeration or freezing operation. This method of preservation may be used in conjunction with other preservation methods such as preservation by thermal processing.

label: preservation by adding sugar
definition: Preservation by adding sugar, sugar syrup or by partial inversion of disaccharides until the sugar concentration is high enough to prevent growth of microorganisms.

parent: aseptic filling and sealing of food
label: food sterilization at ultra high temperature (UHT)
ultra pasteurization (UP) by heat
definition: When used to describe a dairy product, means that such product shall have been thermally processed at or above 138¬∞ C (280¬∞ C) for at least 2 seconds, either before or after packaging so as to produce a product that has extended shelf life under refrigerated conditions (21 CFR 131.3 (c)). Used to describe liquid egg products that also have been thermally processed, but at a different temperature than for milk products.  The egg product will have an extended shelf life under refrigerated conditions.

label: sous vide cooking
definition: Sous-vide, French for "under vacuum", is a method of cooking that is intended to maintain the integrity of ingredients by heating them for an extended period of time in vacuum sealed plastic pouches at relatively low temperatures. Food is cooked for a long time, sometimes well over 24 hours. Unlike cooking in a slow cooker, sous-vide cooking uses airtight plastic bags placed in hot water well below boiling point (usually around 60¬∞C or 140¬∞F).

label: preservation of food component by heat treatment
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when an ingredient or a component of a food has been subjected to preservation by pasteurization, ultrapasteurization or sterilization.

label: ingredient preservation by irradiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when an ingredient or a component of a food has been preservation by irradiation.

label: preservation by adding spices or extracts
definition: Preservation by adding spices or extracts (e.g. garlic, onion, horseradish, paprika) to suppress or inhibit undesirable micro-organisms, enzyme activity, or oxidative changes.

label: preservation by adding inorganic acids or salts
definition: Preservation by adding inorganic acids or salts (e.g. SO2, H2SO4, KNO4, NaNO3) to suppress or inhibit undesirable micro-organisms or enzyme activity.

label: preservation by adding organic acids or salts
definition: Preservation by adding organic acids or salts (e.g. lactic acid, acetic acid, salicylic acid) to suppress or inhibit undesirable micro organisms or enzyme activity.

label: preservation by adding antibiotics
definition: Preservation by adding antibiotics (e.g. nisin, tylosine, subtlin, bacitracin, chlorotetracyclin, oxytetracyclin) to kill micro organisms or stop their growth.

label: food ultra-filtration
definition: Separation of colloidal or very fine solid materials by filtration through microporous or semipermeable mediums. Membranes have pores in the range 2-20 nm diameter.
comment: Some dairy product are ultrafiltrated in order to obtain a higher protein concentration and hereby, a thicker consistency or textture. LanguaL curation note: Used when a product is preservation by the use of ultra-filtration to remove undesirable micro organisms and molecules. Example: beer.

label: ultra high pressure sterilization
definition: The process of holding food at a high pressure, normally greater than 1000 bar, which leads to sterilization. Example: Fruit juice, jam.

label: preservation by electron accelerator radiation
definition: Treated by electron accelerator radiation, for example to kill insects in cereals.

label: disinfection by irradiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when sufficient radiation (e.g. 1-5 k gy) is applied to destroy pathogenic and food spoilage organisms. Example: spices. Radurised food should be stored in a cool and dry place.

label: drying by radiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the water activity is lowered enough by high frequency heating in order to achieve preservation.

label: drying by microwave radiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the water activity is lowered enough by microwave radiation in order to achieve preservation. Also index *WATER REMOVED* in facet H - Treatment applied. Example: tea.

label: drying by infrared heat radiation
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when susceptible materials are dried by electromagnetic radiation with wave-lengths between 0.76um and 1 mm.

label: drying under increased pressure
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when a product is dehydrated under pressure. Example: vegetable or fruit juices, milk.

label: concentration by reverse osmosis
comment: LanguaL curation note: Used when the water content of a product is reduced by reverse osmosis. Typically used for concentrating fluids, e.g. milk, fruit juices.

label: sun drying
definition: Drying by exposure to the sun. Example: cereals, spices, vegetables.

label: food cryogenic freezing
definition: Frozen very rapidly by means of refrigerating agents such as liquid nitrogen or carbon dioxide. Example: lobster frozen in liquid nitrogen.

label: food storage with refrigerating agent process
definition: The process of food storage involving an accompanying refrigerating agent.

parent: preservation by storage in modified atmosphere
label: inert atmosphere storage process
definition: Preservation by storage in inert gases (e.g. nitrogen) to suppress or inhibit undesirable micro-organism growth, oxidation activity, etc.

parent: preservation by storage in modified atmosphere
label: vaccume storage process
definition: Storing under reduced pressure (e.g. 1.3-2 kPa) in order to suppress or inhibit undesirable micro organism growth, oxidation activity, etc.

parent: food cooking|heat treatment food preservation|physical/chemical modification process
label: food blanching
definition: Blanching is a cooking process wherein a food, usually a vegetable or fruit, is scalded in boiling water, removed after a brief, timed interval, and finally plunged into iced water or placed under cold running water (shocking or refreshing) to halt the cooking process. Blanching foods helps reduce quality loss over time. People often use blanching as a pre-treatment prior to freezing, drying, or canning‚Äîheating vegetables or fruits to inactivate enzymes, modify texture, remove the peel, and wilt tissue. Blanching is also utilized to preserve color, flavor, and nutritional value. The process has three stages: preheating, blanching, and cooling. The most common blanching methods for vegetables/fruits are hot water and steam, while cooling is either done using cold water or cool air.
comment: LanguaL definition: "Short time scalding; this can be used to stop emzymatic activity for vegetables being prepared for freezing."

parent: preservation by storage in modified atmosphere
label: controlled atmosphere storage process
definition: Storage of fruits and vegetables in an atmosphere in which the concentrations of oxygen, carbon dioxide (and often nitrogen) are different from those in air and at a low temperature. All three (four) factors are controlled at the desired levels in order to suppress the fruits' and vegetables' natural respiration.

label: food micro-filtration
definition: Microfiltration is used to remove undesirable micro-organisms and molecules. The membranes have pore diameters from 10 to 10000 nm. Micro-filtration is often used instead of pateurisation, e.g. in the brewing industry.

label: high temperature short time (HTST) pasteurization
definition: High Temperature Short Time (HTST) pasteurization is one of the most common methods of pasteurization , which uses metal plates and hot water to raise milk temperatures to at least 72¬∞ C (161¬∞ F) for not less than 15 seconds, followed by rapid cooling.

label: higher heat shorter time (HHST) pasteurization
definition: Higher Heat Shorter Time (HHST) is a process similar to HTST pasteurization, but it uses slightly different equipment and higher temperatures (83 - 127¬∞ C) for a shorter time.

label: ultra high temperature (UHT) pasteurization
definition: Typically involves heating milk or cream to 135¬∞ to 150¬∞ C (275¬∞ to 302¬∞ F) for 1 or 2 seconds. The milk is then packaged in sterile, hermetically-sealed (airtight) containers (aspetic filling) and can be stored without refrigeration for up to 90 days. After opening, spoilage times for UHT products are similar to those of conventionally pasteurized products.
FoodEx2 definition (= scope note): Treating with UHT (Ultra high temperature), processing the product (usually milk) at a temperature of 135 ¬∞C (275 ¬∞F) for a minimum of one second (But in general at a stronger combination of time and temperature)

label: filling conditions for pasteurization
comment: LanguaL curation note: This term is for CLASSIFICATION ONLY; DO NOT USE term in indexing. Use a more precise narrower term.

label: low-temperature-long-time (LTLT) pasteurization
definition: A pasteurization by heating process which uses low heat for a longer time to kill pathogenic bacteria.
comment: An example of LTLT is when milk is pasteurized at 63¬∞ C (145¬∞ F) for 30 minutes.

label: grape crushing
definition: The crushing of whole grapes

label: destemmed grape pressing
definition: A grape pressing process in which whole grapes or destemmed grape must is input directly into a grape press.

label: whole-cluster grape pressing
definition: A grape pressing process in which whole grapes and grape clusters are input directly into a grape press.
comment: By avoiding a maceration process, this technique limits the extraction of phenolics into white wines.

label: grape crushing and destemming
definition: A food component separation process that accomplishes grape crushing and destemming with one device.
comment: This process may be carried out by a "stemmer-crusher" aka "destemmer-crusher".

label: winemaking
definition: A food transformation process which is the production of wine, starting with the selection of the fruit, its fermentation into alcohol, and the bottling or packaging of the finished liquid.

label: wine maceration
definition: A food modification process which is a step in winemaking where the phenolic materials of the grape - tannins, coloring agents (anthocyanins) and flavor compounds - are leached from the grape skins, seeds and stems into the must.

label: conventional maceration
definition: A wine maceration process which occurs in a room temperature environment without other atmospheric controls.????

label: hot maceration
definition: A method of maceration involving high-temperature treatment of grape must before fermentation.
comment: Various techniques of thermo-maceration were developed on the basis of evolution of the industrial technologies. The extraction principle consists in heating the whole grapes or the crushed and destemmed grapes to high temperatures (65‚Äì80‚ó¶C), promoting the diffusion of phenolics from the skins, especially anthocyanins.[https://www.bio-conferences.org/articles/bioconf/full_html/2017/02/bioconf-oiv2017_02032]

label: cold maceration
definition: A wine maceration process in which  temperatures of the fermenting must are kept low to encourage extraction by water and added sulfur dioxide rather than relying principally on heat and alcohol to act as a solvent.

label: limited maceration
definition: A maceration process where seeds and skins of grapes are left in contact with juice or wine for a shorter period of time.

label: extended maceration
definition: A maceration process where seeds and skins of grapes are left in contact with juice or wine for a longer period of time.

label: carbonic maceration
definition: A maceration process in which whole grapes are fermented in a carbon dioxide rich environment before crushing.  Fermentation occurs within grape tissue, rather than from the skin surface.
comment: This method involves filling a sealed vessel with carbon dioxide and then adding whole grapes or grape clusters. ... Carbonic maceration ferments most of the juice while it is still inside the grape, although grapes at the bottom of the vessel are crushed by gravity and undergo conventional fermentation.[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbonic_maceration]

label: normal alcohol fermentation
definition: Conventional alcoholic fermentation involves crushing the grapes to free the juice and pulp from the skin with yeast serving to convert sugar into ethanol.

label: wine secondary alcohol fermentation
definition: The secondary stage of a wine alcohol fermentation and aging process, which takes three to six months, in which the fermentation continues very slowly. The wine is kept under an airlock to protect the wine from oxidation.

label: interrupted alcohol fermentation by sulphur addition
direct heating of container
definition: A heating container process in which the container conducts heat by being in proximity to an open flame, a hot surface or an oven.
comment: The challenge here is to make a clean distinction between methods that immerse a cooking container in water or steam vs those that don't.

label: heating liquid in container
definition: A heating container process in which the temperature of contained liquid is raised to a threshold.
